Excellent JIm, another lesson learnt, I will store that away for future 
re=
ference.

Jim Gilbert wrote:

> Rich,
> Kyo kanagu shi =
is =E4=BA=AC Kyoto =E9=87=91=E5=85=B7 metal fittings =E5=B8=A5 maker.  (Alt=
hough 
> dictionary definitions of this shi kanji are more like master or 
=
> commander, I haven't seen it translated that way for this compound 
> ter=
m.)  I have seen it used as an attribution on both NTHK and NBTHK 
> origam=
i. 
>
> The meaning sounds rather similar to Kyo Kinko (=E4=BA=AC=E9=87=91=
=E5=B7=A5), or Kyoto 
> metalsmith, but in practice usually designates some=
what lower quality 
> work.  A lot of mumei Edo period kozuka and kogai mad=
e in Goto style, 
> but not actually Goto work, will get an attribution to =
Kyo Kinko.  
> Something that deviates further from Goto style and is a bit=
 lower 
> quality will be called Kyo Kanagushi.  That's not an exhaustive 
=
> definition, but I hope it gives you some idea. 
>
> A lot of Edo period k=
inko material isn't distinctive enough to allow 
> an attribution to an ind=
ividual or even a group.  For another example, 
> a lot of later, average, =
unsigned menuki will be attributed to Kyo 
> Kanagushi.  It's not necessari=
ly bad stuff, but there's no way to 
> identify it further.
>
> Your kozuka=
 is probably borderline for passing due to the quality and 
> condition bei=
ng a bit rough, but if it did, the attribution would 
> likely be Kyo kanag=
u shi based on what I've observed.
>
> Jim
>
>
